div1.head: Letter from L. O. Howard to Walter Reed, May 12, 1900
div1.p:
When you were here this afternoon I meant to have
spoken to you about your proposed work with Anopheles at the Arse-
nal, but I had so much to talk about that it escaped my mind.
Will your possible trip to Cuba interrupt this proposed work? If
not, and if you do not go to Cuba, I wished to tell you that almost
any day when you wish to go down there to hunt for Anopheles I will
go with you, or will send one of my assistants to help you, if
you like.

By the way, I meant also to look up before you left the dis-
tribution of Megarhinus and Psorophora. I find now that we have
M. ferox from the District of Columbia, taken August 22nd. M. ruti-
lus we have from North Carolina and Florida. P. ciliata we have
from Massachusetts, New Jersey, Washington, D.C., Kantucky, Nebras-
ka, southern California, Texas, and Florida. The new species of
Megarhinus -- M. portaricensis -- we have from Porto Rica, and from
Benoit, Miss. It was taken at the latter locality last July by
one of my assistants. M. rutilus we have also from Morgantown,
W.Va.
div1.closer:
Yours most truly, L.O. Howard Entomologist.
Dr. Walter Reed, U.S.A.,
Army Medical Museum.
